Colin,
 
Thank you for this background information.  In many gradient descent (or
hill climbing), there are two very real problems.  The first is becoming
stuck in local minima and the second related problem is (as you describe) is
low perturbation potential at some point in time.  The common solution I use
to handle both conditions is a scheduled form of simulated annealing.  This
keeps the plasticity of the topology "pliable" (in NEAT, and in radial basis
function ANN's, we are dealing with both lengths (such as distance, L-p
norms, etc) and weights. But even here, single precision floats properly
normalized will help.  This forms an interesting computational relationship
with mechatronics and bond graphs. Again far off the beaten path, but
interesting.
 
A very important aspect I really didn't want to get into on this project was
the balancing of parallelization paths between tasks run on CPU cores with
kernels run on the GPU process cores, which close-couple with the
partitioning of the data structures between device and host memory sectors.
This discussion may have changed my mind.  Realize, that there will always
exist some resolution limit in the data - even in double-doubles.  I think
that issue becomes a red herring in neuroevolution, for reasons more related
to the probabilistic (non-deterministic) nature of recurrent network graph
structures.  What is evolving is actually a probability density envelope -
representing an ensemble of solutions - not one deterministic answer. Even
as the solution approaches certainty (rho = 0), there may still be an
infinity of solutions in that deterministic solution set.  This is where
cycles of forward and inverse Bayesian refinements are helpful (running on
the CPUs while evolution of genome commences on the GPU).  Again - far off
the track for what I see as the fascinating study of NEAT.
 
So I ask your input, as I also ask of the group: What do want to accomplish
by running n-dimensional substrates NEAT on a hybrid CPU/GPGPU compute node
(or clusters thereof)?  Solutions, or learning opportunities?
 
Ken Lloyd

For the record the default neural net implementation in SharpNeat uses
single precision floats although there are implementations that use
double, and also the genome class uses doubles. Unless there is some
overriding reason you may be aware of (e.g. for the problem domain in
question) then using doubles is probably unnecessary. E.g. I was
recently experimenting with a gradient descent algorithm and noticed
the algorithm stopped with very small learning rates when using single
precision - the reason being that the update increments were simply
too small, that is, when adding a tiny value to a non-zero variable
the true result may require more precision than is available and so
the variable becomes 'stuck'.

I chose floats for a small performance gain on standard CPUs, it's not
necessarily the CPU arithmetic that is faster since CPUs are designed
to do double precision very fast these days, but there will always be
a 2x memory bandwidth benefit with floats and of course gains when
using CUDA, Larabee, SIMD instructions etc.

Colin.
